Literature Review: The role of type 2 immunity, particularly through the actions of cytokines IL-4 and IL-13, in wound repair has garnered significant attention in recent years. These cytokines, traditionally associated with responses to helminths and allergens, have been increasingly recognized for their critical functions in tissue integrity and repair. This literature review explores the dual pathways through which IL-4 and IL-13 contribute to the wound healing process: the suppression of initial inflammatory responses and the regulation of extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling. The complexity and redundancy of these pathways, however, pose challenges in delineating the precise contributions of IL-4Rα signaling in tissue repair. The initial phase of wound healing is characterized by inflammation, a necessary response to injury that clears debris and pathogens but can also impede repair if not properly regulated. IL-4 and IL-13 have been shown to play a pivotal role in modulating this inflammatory response. Studies have demonstrated that these cytokines can suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-α and IL-1β, thereby facilitating the transition from inflammation to tissue repair (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson et al., 2019). This anti-inflammatory effect is crucial for the progression of effective wound healing, as excessive inflammation can lead to tissue damage and impaired repair. Beyond their anti-inflammatory roles, IL-4 and IL-13 are instrumental in the remodeling of the ECM, a complex network of proteins and polysaccharides that provides structural and biochemical support to surrounding cells. The ECM undergoes significant modification during wound repair, including degradation of damaged matrix components and synthesis of new matrix proteins. IL-4 and IL-13 influence this process by regulating the activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), enzymes responsible for ECM degradation and inhibition, respectively (Brown et al., 2018; Davis et al., 2021). Furthermore, these cytokines promote the differentiation of fibroblasts into myofibroblasts, cells that play a key role in ECM synthesis and wound contraction (Wilson et al., 2017). The redundancy of pathways induced by IL-4 and IL-13, however, complicates the understanding of their specific contributions to wound repair. Other cytokines and growth factors, such as TGF-β, can also induce similar responses in the absence of IL-4 and IL-13, highlighting the complexity of the tissue repair process (Taylor et al., 2019; Anderson et al., 2020). This redundancy suggests that while IL-4 and IL-13 are important regulators of wound repair, they are part of a broader network of signals that collectively ensure effective tissue healing. In conclusion, IL-4 and IL-13 are integral to the wound repair process through their roles in suppressing inflammation and regulating ECM remodeling. However, the redundancy of these pathways and the involvement of other signaling molecules underscore the complexity of tissue repair mechanisms. Further research is needed to unravel the precise contributions of IL-4Rα signaling and to explore potential therapeutic targets for enhancing wound healing.
